author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
Alright, it took me almost an entire hour but I got the ETH block data.

Steps so others do not need to endure this sufferfest:

author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
1. Download and run this geth node thingy

https://geth.ethereum.org/downloads/

Once this is installed, you have to run Geth at the command line. You'll wantt to use some special commands: light mode (so you don't have to download the whole blockchain thingy), RPC port, and a large cache helps.

`geth --rpc --rpcapi eth,net,web3,personal --cache=4420 --syncmode light  --rpcport 8545 --rpcaddr 127.0.0.1 --rpccorsdomain "*"`

author: definitelynotcharles7176
content:
2. Download this actually excellent Python package (has a few regular Python dependency jankiness) 

https://github.com/blockchain-etl/ethereum-etl

Run this command to use ethereum-etl

`ethereumetl export_blocks_and_transactions --start-block 11967245 --end-block 11967745 --blocks-output blocks.csv --transactions-output transactions.csv --provider-uri http://localhost:8545/
`

author: definitelynotcharles7176
content: Now you're back to actual civilization with a CSV.
